docs.lead_paragraph: The use of advanced diagnostic imaging like CT and PET scans has soared in recent years, even when doctors do not stand to profit, a study of H.M.O. data has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. - Mitt Romney understands the power of the verbal gaffe, real or perceived. During the Republican primaries, he offered up an all-you-can-eat buffet of them: his wife's ''Cadillacs,'' his friends' Nascar teams, how he liked being able to fire people. Every time, the Obama campaign and its Democratic allies were eager to pounce.

headline.main: Romney Uses Obama's Words Against Him, Calling Him 'Out of Touch'

docs.abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney says Pres Obama is disconnected from real Americans during a campaign stop in Orlando, Fla; calls Obama 'out of touch.' Photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care law, now under review by the Supreme Court, requires states to have health insurance exchanges by January 2014. Some states have made extensive plans, while others have done little.

headline.seo: States’ Progress on Health Insurance Exchanges

docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealthcare’s commitment to keep elements of the health care reform is welcome, but it is not a substitute for the broader mandatory changes under the law.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes UnitedHealthcare's commitment to keeping some of the popular benefits and consumer protections required by the federal health care law, even if the Supreme Court strikes down all or part of it; contends, however, that such voluntary measures on their own will not suffice to fix the fundamental problems of the health system.
docs.snippet: UnitedHealthcare’s commitment to keep elements of the health care reform is welcome, but it is not a substitute for the broader mandatory changes under the law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: When Erika Royer's lupus led to kidney failure four years ago, her father, Radburn, was able to give her an extraordinary gift: a kidney. Ms. Royer, now 31, regained her kidney function, no longer needs dialysis and has been able to return to work. But because of his donation, her father, a physically active 53-year-old, has been unable to obtain private health insurance.

headline.main: The Consumer: The Reward For Donating A Kidney: No Insurance

docs.abstract: Some kidney donors have trouble obtaining private insurance, phenomenon that advocates say may become a powerful detriment to donation; review study published in 2007 found that as many as 11 percent of donors have encountered problems with life and health insurance coverage. Photo (M)t

headline.main: The Reward for Donating a Kidney: No Insurance
headline.print_headline: The Consumer: The Reward For Donating A Kidney: No Insurance

docs.abstract: It is unclear how often kidney donors have trouble obtaining insurance, but advocates say the fear of being uninsurable may be a powerful deterrent to donation.
docs.snippet: It is unclear how often kidney donors have trouble obtaining insurance, but advocates say the fear of being uninsurable may be a powerful deterrent to donation.
